Detailed Description

Supports RTP and RTCP with Symmetric RTP support for NAT traversal.

Author:
Mark Spencer <markster@digium.com>
Note:
RTP is defined in RFC 3550.

Definition in file rtp.c.

01005             }

02481    /* it can change mid call, and SDES can't) */
02482    rtcpheader[len/4]     = htonl((2 << 30) | (1 << 24) | (RTCP_PT_SDES << 16) | 2);
02483    rtcpheader[(len/4)+1] = htonl(rtp->ssrc);               /* Our SSRC */
02484    rtcpheader[(len/4)+2] = htonl(0x01 << 24);                    /* Empty for the moment */
02485    len += 12;
02486    
02487    res = sendto(rtp->rtcp->s, (unsigned int *)rtcpheader, len, 0, (struct sockaddr *)&rtp->rtcp->them, sizeof(rtp->rtcp->them));
02488    if (res < 0) {
02489       ast_log(LOG_ERROR, "RTCP SR transmission error to %s:%d, rtcp halted %s\n",ast_inet_ntoa(rtp->rtcp->them.sin_addr), ntohs(rtp->rtcp->them.sin_port), strerror(errno));
02490       if (rtp->rtcp->schedid > 0)
02491          ast_sched_del(rtp->sched, rtp->rtcp->schedid);
02492       rtp->rtcp->schedid = -1;
02493       return 0;
02494    }
02495    
02496    /* FIXME Don't need to get a new one */
02497    gettimeofday(&rtp->rtcp->txlsr, NULL);
02498    rtp->rtcp->sr_count++;
02499 
02500    rtp->rtcp->lastsrtxcount = rtp->txcount;  
02501    
02502    if (rtcp_debug_test_addr(&rtp->rtcp->them)) {
02503       ast_verbose("* Sent RTCP SR to %s:%d\n", ast_inet_ntoa(rtp->rtcp->them.sin_addr), ntohs(rtp->rtcp->them.sin_port));
02504       ast_verbose("  Our SSRC: %u\n", rtp->ssrc);
02505       ast_verbose("  Sent(NTP): %u.%010u\n", (unsigned int)now.tv_sec, (unsigned int)now.tv_usec*4096);
02506       ast_verbose("  Sent(RTP): %u\n", rtp->lastts);
02507       ast_verbose("  Sent packets: %u\n", rtp->txcount);
02508       ast_verbose("  Sent octets: %u\n", rtp->txoctetcount);
02509       ast_verbose("  Report block:\n");
02510       ast_verbose("  Fraction lost: %u\n", fraction);
02511       ast_verbose("  Cumulative loss: %u\n", lost);
02512       ast_verbose("  IA jitter: %.4f\n", rtp->rxjitter);
02513       ast_verbose("  Their last SR: %u\n", rtp->rtcp->themrxlsr);
02514       ast_verbose("  DLSR: %4.4f (sec)\n\n", (double)(ntohl(rtcpheader[12])/65536.0));
02515    }
02516    return res;
02517 }

03712    const char *s;
03713 
03714    rtpstart = 5000;
03715    rtpend = 31000;
03716    dtmftimeout = DEFAULT_DTMF_TIMEOUT;
03717    cfg = ast_config_load("rtp.conf");
03718    if (cfg) {
03719       if ((s = ast_variable_retrieve(cfg, "general", "rtpstart"))) {
03720          rtpstart = atoi(s);
03721          if (rtpstart < 1024)
03722             rtpstart = 1024;
03723          if (rtpstart > 65535)
03724             rtpstart = 65535;
03725       }
03726       if ((s = ast_variable_retrieve(cfg, "general", "rtpend"))) {
03727          rtpend = atoi(s);
03728          if (rtpend < 1024)
03729             rtpend = 1024;
03730          if (rtpend > 65535)
03731             rtpend = 65535;
03732       }
03733       if ((s = ast_variable_retrieve(cfg, "general", "rtcpinterval"))) {
03734          rtcpinterval = atoi(s);
03735          if (rtcpinterval == 0)
03736             rtcpinterval = 0; /* Just so we're clear... it's zero */
03737          if (rtcpinterval < RTCP_MIN_INTERVALMS)
03738             rtcpinterval = RTCP_MIN_INTERVALMS; /* This catches negative numbers too */
03739          if (rtcpinterval > RTCP_MAX_INTERVALMS)
03740             rtcpinterval = RTCP_MAX_INTERVALMS;
03741       }
03742       if ((s = ast_variable_retrieve(cfg, "general", "rtpchecksums"))) {
03743 #ifdef SO_NO_CHECK
03744          if (ast_false(s))
03745             nochecksums = 1;
03746          else
03747             nochecksums = 0;
03748 #else
03749          if (ast_false(s))
03750             ast_log(LOG_WARNING, "Disabling RTP checksums is not supported on this operating system!\n");
03751 #endif
03752       }
03753       if ((s = ast_variable_retrieve(cfg, "general", "dtmftimeout"))) {
03754          dtmftimeout = atoi(s);
03755          if ((dtmftimeout < 0) || (dtmftimeout > 20000)) {
03756             ast_log(LOG_WARNING, "DTMF timeout of '%d' outside range, using default of '%d' instead\n",
03757                dtmftimeout, DEFAULT_DTMF_TIMEOUT);
03758             dtmftimeout = DEFAULT_DTMF_TIMEOUT;
03759          };
03760       }
03761       ast_config_destroy(cfg);
03762    }
03763    if (rtpstart >= rtpend) {
03764       ast_log(LOG_WARNING, "Unreasonable values for RTP start/end port in rtp.conf\n");
03765       rtpstart = 5000;
03766       rtpend = 31000;
03767    }
03768    if (option_verbose > 1)
03769       ast_verbose(VERBOSE_PREFIX_2 "RTP Allocating from port range %d -> %d\n", rtpstart, rtpend);
03770    return 0;
03771 }

Bridge loop for partial native bridge (packet2packet).

In p2p mode, Asterisk is a very basic RTP proxy, just forwarding whatever rtp/rtcp we get in to the channel.

Note:
this currently only works for Audio

03260          res = AST_BRIDGE_COMPLETE;
03261          break;
03262       } else if ((fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_CONTROL) && !(flags & AST_BRIDGE_IGNORE_SIGS)) {
03263          if ((fr->subclass == AST_CONTROL_HOLD) ||
03264              (fr->subclass == AST_CONTROL_UNHOLD) ||
03265              (fr->subclass == AST_CONTROL_VIDUPDATE)) {
03266             /* If we are going on hold, then break callback mode and P2P bridging */
03267             if (fr->subclass == AST_CONTROL_HOLD) {
03268                if (p0_callback)
03269                   p0_callback = p2p_callback_disable(c0, p0, &p0_iod[0]);
03270                if (p1_callback)
03271                   p1_callback = p2p_callback_disable(c1, p1, &p1_iod[0]);
03272                p2p_set_bridge(p0, NULL);
03273                p2p_set_bridge(p1, NULL);
03274             } else if (fr->subclass == AST_CONTROL_UNHOLD) {
03275                /* If we are off hold, then go back to callback mode and P2P bridging */
03276                ast_clear_flag(p0, FLAG_P2P_SENT_MARK);
03277                p2p_set_bridge(p0, p1);
03278                ast_clear_flag(p1, FLAG_P2P_SENT_MARK);
03279                p2p_set_bridge(p1, p0);
03280                p0_callback = p2p_callback_enable(c0, p0, &p0_iod[0]);
03281                p1_callback = p2p_callback_enable(c1, p1, &p1_iod[0]);
03282             }
03283             ast_indicate_data(other, fr->subclass, fr->data, fr->datalen);
03284             ast_frfree(fr);
03285          } else {
03286             *fo = fr;
03287             *rc = who;
03288             if (option_debug > 2)
03289                ast_log(LOG_DEBUG, "p2p-rtp-bridge: Got a FRAME_CONTROL (%d) frame on channel %s\n", fr->subclass, who->name);
03290             res = AST_BRIDGE_COMPLETE;
03291             break;
03292          }
03293       } else {
03294          if ((fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_DTMF_BEGIN) ||
03295              (fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_DTMF) ||
03296              (fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_VOICE) ||
03297              (fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_VIDEO) ||
03298              (fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_IMAGE) ||
03299              (fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_HTML) ||
03300              (fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_MODEM) ||
03301              (fr->frametype == AST_FRAME_TEXT)) {
03302             ast_write(other, fr);
03303          }
03304 
03305          ast_frfree(fr);
03306       }
03307       /* Swap priority */
03308       cs[2] = cs[0];
03309       cs[0] = cs[1];
03310       cs[1] = cs[2];
03311    }
03312 
03313    /* If we are totally avoiding the core, then restore our link to it */
03314    if (p0_callback)
03315       p0_callback = p2p_callback_disable(c0, p0, &p0_iod[0]);
03316    if (p1_callback)
03317       p1_callback = p2p_callback_disable(c1, p1, &p1_iod[0]);
03318 
03319    /* Break out of the direct bridge */
03320    p2p_set_bridge(p0, NULL);
03321    p2p_set_bridge(p1, NULL);
03322 
03323    return res;
03324 }

00704       +0          - sequence number of DTMF RTP packet (begins from 1,
00705                     wrapped to 0)

00707       +1 (bit 0)     - flaps by different DTMF digits delimited by audio

00713       by each new packet and thus provides some redudancy.

00723       previous digit '2'. Bit +1.0 flips at begin of new digit.
00724       
00725       Cisco RTP DTMF packets comes as replacement of audio RTP packets
00726       so its uses the same sequencing and timestamping rules as replaced
00727       audio packets. Repeat interval of DTMF packets is 20 ms and not rely
00728       on audio framing parameters. Marker bit isn't used within stream of
00729       DTMFs nor audio stream coming immediately after DTMF stream. Timestamps
00730       are not sequential at borders between DTMF and audio streams,
00731    */
